content: The "Comprehensive Strategy for Iraq Act of 2007" includes provisions such as a declaration of policy, expiration of congressional authorization for the use of military force against Iraq, prohibition on establishing permanent US military presence in Iraq, preparation of a US exit strategy from Iraq, assistance for employment and democracy programs in Iraq, appointment of Presidential Special Envoys for Iraq Regional Security, and reporting requirements. The "Comprehensive Strategy for Iraq Act of 2007" includes a declaration of policy. The "Comprehensive Strategy for Iraq Act of 2007" declares the policy of the United States to enhance national security, withdraw military forces from Iraq, and support the elected Government of Iraq in taking responsibility for its resources and security. The "Comprehensive Strategy for Iraq Act of 2007" aims to support reconstruction efforts, promote national reconciliation, provide diplomatic support for stability and democracy, and transfer control of bases to Iraqi Security Forces. The "Comprehensive Strategy for Iraq Act of 2007" aims to support Iraq's sovereignty, control over oil assets, and prosecute terrorist organizations globally. SEC. 3. EXPIRATION OF CONGRESSIONAL AUTHORIZATION FOR USE OF MILITARY FORCE AGAINST IRAQ. Congress finds that the Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Iraq Resolution of 2002 is the sole authority for combat operations in Iraq. It authorized the use of the Armed Forces to defend national security against the threat posed by Iraq and enforce relevant UN Security Council resolutions. The original missions assigned to the Armed Forces included identifying and destroying Iraqi weapons of mass destruction capabilities, preventing support for international terrorism, and ending the Iraqi Government's actions. The Iraq Study Group concluded that sectarian violence is the main challenge to stability in Iraq. If the authority under Public Law 107-243 is terminated, the President cannot continue combat operations in Iraq without specific authorization from Congress. The authority for the President to use the Armed Forces as provided by Public Law 107-243 expires on December 31, 2007. No other law can be interpreted as providing authority for combat operations in Iraq. SEC. 4 prohibits the use of funds for a permanent US military presence in Iraq. SEC. 5 requires the preparation and submission of a US exit strategy from Iraq. The President must submit a report to Congress within 30 days outlining a strategy to end combat operations in Iraq. The strategy should include a plan to phase out the number of troops in Iraq by December 31, 2007, and a timetable for withdrawing the Armed Forces with specific objectives for troop reductions. The President must submit a report to Congress within 30 days outlining a strategy to end combat operations in Iraq, including troop reductions before December 31, 2007, and a plan for turning over authority for all remaining security and government operations in Iraq to the Government of Iraq. Additionally, the report should include an assessment of the need for a military mission after December 31, 2007, focusing on advisory roles and maintaining a regional counterterrorism strike force. The report to Congress must include a strategy to end combat operations in Iraq, troop reductions by December 31, 2007, and transferring authority for security and government operations to the Government of Iraq. It should also assess the training and fielding needs of Iraqi Security Forces and reconstruction needs in Iraq. Assistance for employment programs and democracy, governance, and related programs in Iraq. Assistance authorized for employment projects in Iraq, contingent on the Government of Iraq reaching a power-sharing agreement among ethnic and sectarian factions. $2 billion authorized for fiscal years 2008-2010. President authorized $2 billion for fiscal years 2008-2010 to provide assistance for democracy, governance, human rights, rule of law, and religious freedom in Iraq. At least 50% of funds must support democratic institutions at local and provincial levels. $300 million authorized annually for this purpose. President authorized $2 billion for fiscal years 2008-2010 to provide assistance for democracy, governance, human rights, rule of law, and religious freedom in Iraq. At least 50% of funds must support democratic institutions at local and provincial levels. $300 million authorized annually for this purpose. SEC. 7. PRESIDENTIAL SPECIAL ENVOYS FOR IRAQ REGIONAL SECURITY. The President shall appoint two Presidential Special Envoys for Iraq Regional Security within 15 days of the enactment of this Act. The envoys will engage with the Government of Iraq and neighboring countries to support peace efforts and prevent regional instability. They will also organize a regional conference on Iraq's future involving various stakeholders. The President appoints two Special Envoys for Iraq Regional Security to engage with Iraq and neighboring countries, organize a regional conference, and support peace efforts. Countries like Egypt, Iran, Jordan, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Syria, and Turkey will form an Iraq Support Group to coordinate policies for peace and stability. Additionally, there will be a forum for national reconciliation negotiations in Iraq. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal year 2008. SEC. 8. REPORT. The Secretary of State must submit a report to Congress within 60 days of this Act's enactment. The report will cover efforts to promote regional dialogue on Iraq's future, financial assistance pledges for Iraq's relief and reconstruction, and efforts to encourage other countries to fulfill their pledges. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. Congress believes the US should redeploy assets to complete Operation Enduring Freedom, defeat Taliban and al Qaeda forces in Afghanistan, and dismantle terrorist networks globally.
